content.text: Medieval logicians, working primarily in European universities, preserved and extended Aristotelian logic. They developed sophisticated theories of meaning, reference, and inference that would remain influential for centuries.

content.definition: A medieval theory of reference explaining how terms in propositions 'stand for' (supposit for) things. Different contexts give terms different kinds of supposition.

content.text: **William of Ockham** (c.1287-1347) was a leading medieval logician. He refined supposition theory and is famous for 'Ockham's Razor': entities should not be multiplied beyond necessity — prefer simpler explanations.

content.title: Types of Supposition
premises: 'Man is a species' — 'man' has simple supposition (refers to the concept)
'Man is a noun' — 'man' has material supposition (refers to the word itself)
'Man runs' — 'man' has personal supposition (refers to actual men)
content.note: The same word can 'stand for' different things depending on context.

content.text: Medieval logicians also developed the theory of **consequences** — rules for valid inference. They classified consequences as formal (valid by form alone) or material (valid due to the content of terms).
Peter of Spain's Summulae Logicales became the standard logic textbook, used in universities for centuries. It systematized Aristotelian logic and medieval innovations.

content.question: What was supposition theory about?
options: How to make assumptions in proofs
How terms in propositions refer to things
content.explanation: Supposition theory explained how terms 'stand for' or refer to things. The same term could have different reference depending on its context in the proposition.
